paper_abstract: Cyclicity of a convolutional code ( CC) is relying on a nontrivial automorphism of the algebra F[x]/(x(n) - 1), where F is a finite field. A particular choice of the data leads to the class of doubly-cyclic CC's. Within this large class Reed-Solomon and BCH convolutional codes can be defined. After constructing doubly-cyclic CC's, basic properties are derived on the basis of which distance properties of Reed-Solomon convolutional codes are investigated. This shows that some of them are optimal or near optimal with respect to distance and performance.
